The building’s ambition extended beyond its structural innovation, with the multi-story design featuring flexible, modular spaces that aimed to serve as a multi-use facility within Poly Canyon. Although the project faced challenges, including structural misalignment and limited success with environmental features, the building remains an important part of architectural history for its vision, daring experimentation, and integration of unconventional materials and techniques.

This structure’s attempt to use water as a structural element represented a leap into uncharted territory for architectural engineering, merging the principles of ecological building and technological advancement in a way that was ahead of its time. While the project never fully materialized as intended, it paved the way for future explorations in innovative and adaptive architectural practices.

images.description: Main image of the Hydraulic House.
A scanned image of the finished hydraulic house.
An original photo from CAED photo lab showing the digging and work of the foundation for the hydraulic house.

structures.description: Built in 1967 by a Poly Royal crew, the tree house and accompanying gate were once situated near the entrance of the canyon, predating the stone archway. Originally designed as a playful, elevated platform among the sycamores, the structure’s charm faded over time. A 1982 repair list noted it needed preservative treatment, hinting at its gradual decay. By 1987, the tree house was missing its ladder, and a rare photograph captured its final years. Now vanished without a trace, it lingers in memory as a curious remnant of a bygone era, shrouded in mystery despite its once-prominent location.

images.description: Main image of the Tree House.
A modern day photo of the tree near the entrance that the tree house used to sit on.

structures.description: The Exercise Station structures were developed as part of a broader vision to integrate physical fitness with the natural environment. Conceptualized in 1973 and refined in 1974, these stations featured equipment for exercises like pull-ups and sit-ups, blending recreation with fitness. However, the structures are now considered ghost projects—their exact locations are unknown, and no physical remains have been identified. They serve as a fascinating glimpse into experimental outdoor fitness design.
structures.extended_description: The project evolved over two years, beginning with a 1973 thesis that focused heavily on the conceptual aspects of integrating jogging routes with structured exercise stops. This initial plan outlined a European-inspired fitness circuit but tailored it to the canyon's terrain and the needs of Cal Poly’s community. The 1974 thesis expanded on this foundation, shifting focus to the design and imagined construction of specific exercise structures. Featuring whimsical sketches and practical insights, the work emphasized accessibility and functionality. Though the stations were never fully documented in the field and their exact locations remain unknown, they stand as a testament to the creative experimentation of student-led fitness and design projects. An old photograph confirms at one point, at least one of the structures was built.

images.description: Main image of the Exercise Structure.
An original sketch from the thesis, that depicts a general outline of the Cal Poly exercise circuit.
An original sketch from the thesis, that shows the creativity and the details of the project.

structures.description: The Tensegrity Mast, constructed in 1975 by students under Jack Peterson’s guidance, was a striking structural experiment placed prominently on a knoll in the canyon. The mast’s history is marked by cycles of vandalism and repair, with wires cut and turnbuckles loosened during its early years, causing repeated collapses. Photographs show it lying horizontal before briefly being reassembled upright in 1978. By 1982, plans were made to rewire and move it back to its original location, but it was never fully restored. While the mast itself is long gone, its original foundations remain visible near the site of the Tensegrity structure, serving as a tangible reminder of its ambitious legacy.

images.description: Main image of the Tensegrity Mast.
The student builders of the tensegrity mass carrying it out to the canyon during Design Village.
A modern day photo of the foundations for the tensegrity mass.

structures.description: The Cor-X house, built in 1982, was a lightweight plastic structure with aluminum framing constructed by a Crop Sciences major and an Architecture major. Designed as a low-cost, portable housing experiment, the structure featured polystyrene insulation, an RV-style toilet, and a unique greenhouse-style front door. Its purpose was to promote sustainable housing solutions for disaster relief and developing countries. Though functional during its time, the house has since vanished, leaving its foundations near the modern-day Fratessa Tower as the only trace of its existence.

images.description: Main image of the Cor X structure.
From the original newspaper article, an inside image of the CorX house.
From the original newspaper article, an image showing off the working refirgerator in the house.
From the original newspaper article, an image showing off Duddles on his sleeping bag.

structures.description: The Accessory Shed, completed in 2022, was an asymmetrical wooden shed designed to explore the undervalued architectural style of California’s Central Valley. Built with CDX plywood and featuring a pitched roof, raised heel truss, and overhanging eaves, the structure deliberately lacked windows or doors, drawing focus to its external design. Its imbalanced form and exaggerated proportions challenged traditional perceptions of utility buildings while providing shade and scenic views. Positioned near the top of the canyon, the structure had no accessible interior and no functional purpose, and it has since been removed.

images.description: Main image of the Accessory Shed.
The builder of the shed accessory posing in front of the finished creation.
The foundation of the shed, still present today.

structures.description: The Cow Fence, estimated to have been built in 1965, was an early structure designed to keep cows out of the area designated for projects at the time. Crafted from an array of vertical wooden posts, the gate combined functionality with a whimsical aesthetic. It's believed to have been near the current entrance to the canyon, slightly north of its current location. Intended to allow people to pass freely while serving as a barrier for livestock, little is known about the structure beyond a photograph found in George Hasslein’s scrapbook, which depicts him walking through the gate.

images.description: Main image of the Cow Fence.

structures.description: The Compressed Earth Blocks project, developed in 1965, was an effort by five architectural engineering students to explore sustainable construction methods using locally sourced materials. The team designed and tested dozens of compressed earth blocks (CEBs) for durability, load-bearing capacity, and fire resistance. Though initially part of a more ambitious plan, the focus on CEBs demonstrated the potential of low-cost, eco-friendly materials for future canyon projects.
structures.extended_description:
Originally envisioned as a large-scale "Experimental Design Laboratory," the project aimed to create a dedicated space for architectural innovation and education within the canyon. The proposed lab included workspaces for sixteen students, offices for instructors, and shared areas for seminars and discussions, all framed by the natural landscape. However, the ambitious scope, coupled with resource and time constraints, led the team to pivot toward the more attainable goal of developing compressed earth blocks (CEBs).

Using soil from the surrounding area, the students crafted and tested CEBs, highlighting their strength, fire resistance, and cost-effectiveness compared to traditional masonry. Treated with waterproofing agents and optimized for earthquake resilience, the blocks showcased the viability of sustainable, locally sourced materials in construction. While the Experimental Design Laboratory itself was never realized, the CEB research stands as a testament to the team's adaptability and innovative spirit, offering valuable insights into resource-efficient building practices.

images.description: Main image of the Compressed Earth Blocks project.
From the thesis, an image depicts the students working on some of the original earth blocks.
From the thesis, an image depicts students working on the process of forming the earth blocks.

structures.description: The Windmill, a ghost structure documented through a single photograph, remains an enigma. Believed to have responded to changes in wind direction, its precise purpose and construction details are unknown, although its location has been deciphered from the photo. In 1982, there was a mention of possibly rebuilding or designing a new windmill, but no further information has surfaced. Its fleeting presence adds a layer of intrigue to the sculpture.

images.description: Main image of the Sculptural Windmill.
